name: Baker McKenzie
title: AI-Driven Support Staff Restructuring with Attorney Firewall

classification.classificationRationale: Decision tree: Formal AI unit? NO — no CAIO, no AI lab, no dedicated AI team described. The restructuring is enterprise-wide adoption of Anthropic Claude Cowork, deployed across support functions (research, marketing, knowledge management, secretarial) while explicitly excluding attorneys. This is mass adoption without formal structure = M6a. Contextual orientation: same organization deploys AI across functions without structural separation. Low confidence: single source, restructuring announcement rather than observed org structure. Guardrails checked: G5 (not AI-native — founded 1949 as law firm), G6 (one-time restructuring, not temporal cycling).

description:
Baker McKenzie announced cuts of 600-1,000 support positions as part of an AI-driven restructuring in February 2026, representing approximately 10% of its global workforce. Affected functions include research staff, marketing, knowledge management, and secretarial roles, while attorney positions were explicitly excluded from the cuts.

The restructuring is notable for citing Anthropic's Claude Cowork AI agent as a specific catalyst enabling automation of legal tasks and documentation. Geographic impact spans dozens of positions in London and Belfast with hundreds more across global operations. The firm framed the restructuring as 'rethinking the ways in which we work, including through our use of AI, introducing efficiencies, and investing in those roles that best serve our clients' needs.'

The attorney-exclusion firewall is structurally significant: it reveals a two-tier organizational response to AI where fee-earning professionals are protected while support functions absorb the displacement. This pattern may be characteristic of professional services firms where the core product is human expertise and judgment.
